comment.author: 51035826751@N01
comment._content: Early photo exposures took a while; subjects had to sit/stand still for a few moments for the film to take an image. It would have been trivial for someone to stand in front of the man for a few seconds just long enough to leave a ghostly image.

comment.author: 21061284@N05
comment._content: Search William Hope. He was one of the premiere spirit photographers of the early Twentieth Century and was considered by believers and supporters to be a true master of the art of producing spirits on ordinary photographic plates. To others, he was a clever trickster and while he had more than his share of detractors, he was often accused of fraud but was never caught at it -- thanks to the controversy that surrounded the main attempt to expose him.

comment.author: 27556643@N03
comment._content: I know that most people of 80 years ago didn't have much of an understanding of the basic principles and mechanics behind the relatively new, and still quite complicated art of photography.  And so they could be easily fooled by fakes such as this one.  And I also know that they were still more casually able to believe in "ghosts" and other kinds of "boogins" without feeling embarrassed or being seen as acting childish.  But what is our excuse today for not just simply laughing at this painfully obvious fake image?  It should be obvious as a fake to any rational adult alive today, and anyone who has ever taken even a basic high school photography class should be able to look at this image and in two seconds know multiple techniques that could have been used in it's creation.  Double exposures, a face from one image cut out and placed into another, long exposure times and any of a million different things causing the "ghostly" form in the original image, rephotographing an original photo with modifications made to it.  All are infinitely more plausible explanations than the one completely absurd conclusion that many people seem to instantly jump to.

comment.author: 23352562@N06
comment._content: Really absurd.  Notice how the face is extremely sharp, including a jawline that appears cut out, yet the rest of the "spirit" is blurred, wispy, and doesn't appear to even conform to a human shape.  Shows you what could be accomplished with a simple "burning and dodging" process in the darkroom...although pretty sloppily.
